Florence Nightingale was born in 1820. Her parents gave her an excellent education, but two hundred years ago the daughters of rich parents didn’t have careers. Their families expected them to get married and stay at home. But Florence wanted to be a nurse and look after sick people. In 1854 she travelled to Turkey. At that time, Britain and some other countries were fighting a war against Russia. Florence worked very hard to improve the care of injured soldiers in the hospital. She became famous all over the world for her work there.
Florence started a school for nurses in 1864 and, for the first time, being a nurse became a real job. She also understood that it was very important to keep things clean in hospitals. Florence died in 1910 at the age of ninety.
content.explanation: This section tests reading comprehension and vocabulary related to a historical figure.

chapters.title: Businessperson of the Year Reading Comprehension

content.passage:
Henrietta Dawson, a businessperson from Portsmouth, is the new Businessperson of the Year. Henrietta heard she had won the prize at a dinner in London last night.
‘I can’t believe I won the title!’ Henrietta said when she found out. ‘There are hundreds of good, hard-working businesspeople out there, so when people tell you that you’re the best it’s just fantastic.’
Hendrietta runs three companies that make food and drink to sell to hotels and restaurants in and around her hometown. ‘I couldn’t have done it without my parents and husband. They’ve given me a lot of help,’ Henrietta said.
Hendrietta’s mother was also a successful businessperson and taught her daughter that anything is possible if you work hard. Henrietta is also lucky because her husband, Pete, put his own career on hold to look after their two young children.
Hendrietta is the first woman to win the title. Last year’s winner, Tom Lawson, who runs a successful tourism company, was at the dinner too. ‘The competition is an important way to get people interested in starting their own businesses,’ he told the audience. ‘Of course, not everyone wants to do it, but you don’t need to come from a rich family to be a successful businessperson.’
Hendrietta could one day be a rich woman. But she isn’t one yet; the money she makes goes back into her businesses, not into her pocket.
content.explanation: This section tests reading comprehension about a business profile.

questions.question: Henrietta
options: has food and drink companies in Portsmouth.
sells hotels and restaurants in her hometown.
has companies which sell food and drink in London.

questions.question: Henrietta
options: wasn’t surprised when she won the title.
was told by many businesspeople that she was the best.
didn’t know she would win the competition.

questions.question: Henrietta’s husband
Tom thinks the competition is important
options: because everyone is interested in starting a business.
because it shows that business is not only for some people.
because anyone can run a business.

questions.question: Henrietta
options: might be rich in the future.
uses her money to start new businesses.

content.passage:
Gerald
When I was a boy, my parents worked in Africa for two years. We visited lots of exciting places there and I have loved travelling and exploring since then. I usually choose to travel alone because it is easier to meet people that way. I often stay with the new friends I make on my journeys, and finding out about new cultures is my favourite part of exploring.
Simone
My favourite places are in the cold parts of the world. There are some areas, covered in snow and ice, where almost no one has ever been before. I usually go on foot because there are no roads. I plan my trips very carefully – I like to be well prepared and I take lots of special equipment with me. I sometimes go for days and weeks without seeing other people – I like the opportunity that gives me to think about my life and to make plans.
Frank
I do most of my exploring by boat. It can take me weeks to get somewhere I could drive to in a day, but it is all about the journey. I always take someone else because my boat needs two people and I don’t think I would like to go alone. There usually aren’t many people at all in the places that I explore, so I don’t often meet new people. My boat is quite small so I can get to places that other, bigger boats can’t get to. That makes travelling even more interesting.
content.explanation: This section tests reading comprehension about different explorers' preferences and experiences.

questions.question: Who enjoys being alone?
Who likes learning about the different ways that people live?
Who explores places that you cannot get to by car?
Who has to travel with another person?
Who thinks a lot about what to take with them?
Who spent time away from home when they were young?
Who explains why their transport is better than others?
